s.text: Which means that in the diaspora, Chineseness is not a more authentic way of being; it is just a decision to act Chinese.
And the presumption that Chinese-Americans are merely Chinese people who happen to be in America, who could just as easily be in Indonesia or Malaysia, strikes me as fallacious, even dangerous.
So long as minorities strike a pose of diasporan dispossession, they give tacit approval to a notion of "prior" Americanness that excludes them.
Consider the question of the "overseas Chinese," which is how people in China and Taiwan refer to the 30 million or so ethnic Chinese who live elsewhere.
I have, after all, no particular knack for business.
For most hyphenated Americans, a trip to the ancestral lands is enough to reinforce the point--assuming, that is, that there are ancestral lands to speak of.
For most hyphenated Americans, a trip to the ancestral lands is enough to reinforce the point--assuming, that is, that there are ancestral lands to speak of.
